column1: Lake Oswego  is a city in the State of Oregon
column2: primarily in Clackamas County with small portions extending into neighboring Multnomah and Washington counties. Located about 8 miles (13 km) south of Portland and surrounding the 405-acre (164 ha) Oswego Lake
column3: the town was founded in 1847 and incorporated as Oswego in 1910. The city was the hub of Oregon's brief iron industry in the late 19th century
column4: and is today a suburb of Portland.  The population in 2010 was 36
column6: a 3.8% increase over the 2000 population of 35

column1: The Clackamas Indians once occupied the land that later became Lake Oswego
column2: but diseases transmitted by European explorers and traders killed most of the natives. Before the influx of non-native people via the Oregon Trail
column3: the area between the Willamette River and Tualatin River had a scattering of early pioneer homesteads and farms.

column2: encouraged by the Donation Land Claim Act of 1850 and the subsequent Homestead Act
column3: they found the land underoccupied.

column1: Albert Alonzo Durham founded the town of Oswego in 1847
column2: naming it after Oswego
column3: New York. He built a sawmill on Sucker Creek (now Oswego Creek)
column5: the federal government forcibly relocated the remaining Clackamas Indians to the Grand Ronde Indian Reservation in nearby Yamhill County.During this early period in Oregon history
column6: most trade proceeded from Portland to Oregon City via the Willamette River
column7: and up the Tualatin River Valley through Tualatin
column9: and Hillsboro. The thick woods and rain-muddied roads were major obstacles to traveling by land. The vestiges of river landings
column11: and covered bridges of this period can still be seen along this area. A landing in the city's present-day George Rogers Park is thought to have been developed by Durham around 1850 for lumber transport; another landing was near the Tryon Creek outlet into the Willamette.

column2: prompted by the earlier discovery of iron ore in the Tualatin Valley
column3: the Oregon Iron Company was incorporated. Within two years
column4: the first blast furnace on the West Coast was built
column5: patterned after the arched furnaces common in northwestern Connecticut
column6: and the company set out to make Oswego into the "Pittsburgh of the West". In 1878
column7: the company was sold off to out-of-state owners and renamed the Oswego Iron Company
column9: Portland financiers Simeon Gannett Reed and Henry Villard purchased the business and renamed it the Oregon Iron and Steel Company.

column1: The railroad arrived in Oswego in 1886
column2: in the form of the Portland and Willamette Valley Railway. A seven-mile-long line provided Oswego with a direct link to Portland. Prior to this
column3: access to the town was limited to primitive roads and riverboats. The railroad's arrival was a mixed blessing; locally
column4: it promoted residential development along its path
column5: which enabled Oswego to grow beyond its industrial roots
column7: the continued expansion of freight railroad system gave easy local access to cheaper and higher quality iron from the Great Lakes region. This ultimately led to the local industry's demise.By 1890
column10: and at its peak provided employment to around 300 men. The success of this industry greatly stimulated the development of Oswego
column11: which by this time had four general stores
column18: and even an opera house.The iron industry was a vital part of a strategy designed by a few Portland financiers who strove to control all related entrepreneurial ventures in the late 19th century. Control of shipping and railroads was held under the Oregon Steam Navigation Company
column19: later to become the Oregon Railway and Navigation Company. This local monopoly responded to the area's increasing demand for iron and steel
column20: and grew to play a key role in economic history throughout the area.

column6: and erecting power poles in subsequent years to supply power to Oswego citizens. With the water needs of the smelters tailing off
column7: the recreational potential of the lake and town was freed to develop rapidly.In 1910
column8: the town of Oswego was incorporated. The Southern Pacific Railroad
column9: which had acquired the P&WVR line at the end of the 19th century
column10: widened it from narrow to standard gauge and in 1914
column14: and quiet service between Oswego and Portland.  The service was known as the Red Electric.Passenger traffic hit its peak in 1920 with 64 trains to and from Portland daily. Within nine years of the peak
column15: passenger service ended and the line was used for intermittent freight service to  Portland's south waterfront until its abandonment in 1984. The line was preserved
column17: and the Willamette Shore Trolley provides tourist rides on the line today.

column1: One of the land developers benefiting from sales by OI&S was Paul Murphy
column2: whose Oswego Lake Country Club helped promote the new city as a place to "live where you play." Murphy was instrumental in developing the first water system to supply the western reaches of the city
column3: and also played a key role in encouraging the design of fine homes in the 1930s and 1940s that ultimately established Oswego as an attractive place to live. In the 1940s and 1950s
column4: continued development helped spread Oswego's residential areas.Mass transit service after the end of electric interurban service was provided by Oregon Motor Stages
column5: but that company suspended all operations following a drivers strike in 1954. In 1955
column9: began operating bus service connecting Oswego with downtown Portland and Oregon City.  This service was taken over by TriMet in 1970.

column2: Oswego was renamed Lake Oswego when it annexed part of neighboring Lake Grove. The city has some nicknames including Lake No-Negro
column3: Lake Big Ego
column4: Fake Oswego and Fake Lost Ego. Additionally
column5: it was spoken of as Nimbyville during a planning-related seminar on 2008 by Dennis Egner. A 2012 article in the Daily Journal of Commerce identified Egner as a long-range planning director for the City of Lake Oswego. According to historian James W. Loewen
column6: locals often call it "Lake No Negro" in reference to its recognition status as an "elite white suburb".In August 2020
column7: Lake Oswego received significant media attention when its resident received an anonymous letter from neighbors asking them to take down their "Black Lives Matter" sign from the window complaining that it lowers property values
column8: which prompted Mayor Studebaker to issue a response to this matter.

column1: The city has a council-manager form of government
column2: which vests policy-making authority in an elected
column3: volunteer city council. The council consists of a mayor and six councilors
column4: all of whom are elected at-large and serve four-year terms.Day-to-day operations are handled by an appointed
column5: professional city manager. Almost all of the city's employees
column6: which include part-time staff amounting to about 342 full-time equivalents

column1: Oswego Lake has been a subject of controversy over whether it is a private lake or a public navigable water. A lawsuit against the city charges that they are preventing people from using a public stairway in a public park to swim in a public lake. The City of Lake Oswego does not allow public access. Two recreational users of the lake who were barred from using the lake filed a lawsuit in 2012. On August 1
column3: the Oregon Supreme Court ruled that a 2012 Lake Oswego ordinance will need to be reviewed. The Supreme Court recognized public right to enter the body of water from public land and that the City of Lake Oswego cannot interfere with this right.

column1: The Lake Oswego School District is within the city boundaries and serves the city's roughly 7
column2: 000 students
column3: with a ratio of 23 students per instructor. The two high schools in the district are Lake Oswego High School and Lakeridge High School. The six elementary schools and two junior high schools serve students in grades 1 through 8. The junior high schools are Lakeridge Junior High and Lake Oswego Junior High. Lakeridge Junior High was known as Waluga Junior High until 2012 when it was merged with Bryant Elementary.

column1: The city maintains 600 acres (2.4 km2) of parks and open spaces including George Rogers Park and Millennium Plaza Park.
Lake Oswego has one public library
column2: part of the Library Information Network of Clackamas County. From 2002 to 2006
column3: the library was rated among the top 10 libraries serving similar population sizes in the United States.
